item.title: 2017 Great Lakes Areas of Concern Conference

item.title: 2016 AOCs Conference Presentations
item.description:
Presentations given at the 2016 Great Lakes AOCs Conference in Dearborn, Mich.

Success Stories videos

  • Menekaunee Harbor: Bringing the Harbor to Life (05:12) Exit
  • Shifting Sands Trailer (01:40) Exit
  • Bringing Back the Black River (03:23) Exit

Sturgeon videos

  • Sturgeon Habitat Restoration on St. Louis River AOC (03:32) Exit
  • Stocking Genesee River With Lake Sturgeon Helps Gauge River's Health (02:09) Exit
  • Lower Menominee Sturgeon Passage (04:07) Exit
  • St. Clair River Spawning Habitat Restoration (06:16) Exit

Presentations

  • Guidance on How to Remove BUIs Exit- John Perrecone & Megan O’Brien
  • Final Agenda for the Great Lakes AOCs Conference (PDF)(4 pp, 548 K, Feb. 26, 2016)
  • 2016 AOC Conference Attendees (PDF)(6 pp, 303 K, March 2016)
    List of names & organizations of 2016 AOC Conference attendees
  • Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement Annex 1 Update (PDF)(11 pp, 477 K, March 2016)
    Wendy Carney gives a progress report on the AOC program and discusses the recent situation analysis and AOC in Recovery documents.
  • Getting Work Done at AOCs: How are the Federal GLRI agencies implementing the AOC program? (PDF)(19 pp, 4 MB, March 2016)
    Marc Tuchman gives an update and overview of the AOC program including recent accomplishments.
  • Program Federal Partners Technical Support to AOCs (PDF)(32 pp, 5 MB, March 2016)
    Federal Partners (USGS, USACE, USFWS, NOAA) give examples on the technology, tools, and staff expertise that can help AOCs develop overall program goals and objectives, as well as assist with special projects (e.g., habitat plans), toward a comprehensive pathway to delisting.
  • Long-Term Sustainability for Habitat Restoration (PDF)(4 pp, 286 K, March 2016)
    Scott Cieniawski describes the important factors to consider when developing a monitoring and maintenance plan for GLRI Habitat Restoration Projects
  • Maintenance, Monitoring and Evaluation of Habitat Restoration Projects (PDF)(5 pp, 897 K, March 2016)
    Julie Sims presents how NOAA addresses project management, monitoring and evaluation.
  • St. Louis River Area of Concern Pre and Post Construction Monitoring (PDF)(12 pp, 1 MB, March 2016)
    Nelson French describes the evaluation of habitat restoration projects in the St. Louis River Estuary AOC.
  • Maintenance and Monitoring of GLRI Habitat Projects (PDF)(13 pp, 3 MB, March 2016)
    Jason Hill presents the Ducks Unlimited process to monitoring and implement maintenance actions on their GLRI projects, for the long-term.
  • Maintenance and Monitoring of Habitat Restoration Projects (PDF)(21 pp, 4 MB, March 2016)
    Carl Platz presents the USACE approach to establishing success criteria and ensuring long-term sustainability
  • Results of R2R2R Interactive Polling (PDF)(5 pp, 330 K, March 2016)
    Joel Hoffman and Katie Williams used audience participation to gain understanding on revitalization activities in AOC communites and how they are linked to remediation and restoration.
  • Remediation-Restoration-Revitalization: Past practices and emerging trends in the greening of brownfields (PDF)(33 pp, 9 MB, March 2016)
    Chris De Sousa describes the transformation of Brownfield sites to green spaces that benefit communities. Case studies of Milwaukee (Menomonee Valley) and Minneapolis (Mill Ruins Park).
  • Delisting AOCs Under the New Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement (PDF)(6 pp, 496 K, March 2016)
    Wendy Carney gives an overview of the steps involved in the AOC delisting process including the new requirements created by the 2012 GLWQA.
  • Monitoring for BUI Removal: Loss of fish habitat & Degradation of fish populations (PDF)(3 pp, 262 K, March 2016)
    Carl Reutz describes the fish monitoring for loss of habitat and degraded populations BUI at the Muskegon AOC.
  • Fish and Wildlife Consumption BUI: Michigan's Tiered Approach (PDF)(4 pp, 66 K, March 2016)
    Joe Bohr outlines Michigan's tiered approach to removal of the fish consumption BUI.
  • Benthos and Plankton Assessments (PDF)(8 pp, 706 K, March 2016)
    Barbara Scudder Eikenberry describes the USGS assessment of Plankton and Benthos BUIs in Wisconsin AOCs.
  • Social Media in the AOCs Showcase (PDF)(9 pp, 1 MB, March 2016)
    Caitie Nigrelli offers advice and examples for AOC practitioners on how to be successful using various social media platforms.
  • Twitter 101 (PDF)(1 pg, 59 K, March 2016)
    Take-home guidelines for improving communication efforts
  • Live-Tweeting Tip Sheet (PDF)(1 pg, 49 K, March 2016)
    Take home guidelines for improving communication efforts
  • AOC Social Media Tweet Cheat Sheet (PDF)(3 pp, 300 K, March 2016)
    Take home guidelines for improving communication efforts
  • Lake Sturgeon Success Stories in the Great Lakes (PDF)(27 pp, 6 MB, March 2016)
    Partners from across the Great Lakes basin describe their successes in restoring sturgeon populations.
  • Analysis of Sediment Remediation Outreach in the Great Lakes Region: A Mixed-Methods Approach (PDF)(11 pp, 1 MB, March 2016)
    Nicole Machuca presents research that utilizes social science research methods to analyze AOC resident’s attitudes, as to inform outreach.
  • The management of stakeholder and public participation at US and binational AOCs: Overcoming challenges and looking beyond delisting (PDF)(12 pp, 613 K, March 2016)
    Katie Williams describes a study of stakeholder and public participation across AOCs.
  • Community Voice in the Milwaukee Estuary AOC (PDF)(14 pp, 347 MB, March 2016)
    Kaitlyn Hornik explores stakeholder perspectives on urban environmental remediation projects. Milwaukee case study reveals local redistribution of environmental benefits and burdens.
  • Possibilities of Place: Awareness and Perceptions of the White Lake and Muskegon Lake Areas of Concern (PDF)(16 pp, 391 K, March 2016)
    Sherwood Smith presents the results of research on attitudes of the White Lake and Muskegon AOCs .
  • Muskegon Lake: An AOC case study combining science, community, and philanthropy (PDF)(19 pp, 3 MB, March 2016)
    Al Steinman uses Muskegon Lake AOC as a case study for habitat restoration plan and long-term monitoring projects.
  • U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service Providing Technical Guidance for the Great Lakes’ AOCs: Degradation of Habitat and Populations BUIs (PDF)(11 pp, 2 MB, March 2016)
    Mandy Annis presents the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service scientific role and ability to provide technical guidance for the Degradation of Habitat and Populations BUIs.
  • Combined BUI Analysis: Loss of Fish and Wildlife Habitat & Degraded Fish and Wildlife Populations (PDF)(13 pp, 2 MB, March 2016)
    Megan O'Brien explores the differences between how states handle Degraded Fish & Wildlife Populations and Loss of Fish & Wildlife Habitat BUIs from target setting through impairment removal.
  • The Great Lakes Legacy Act: The Role of Non-Federal Partners (PDF)(11 pp, 1 MB, March 2016)
    Marc Tuchman outlines the success of the GLLA program and describes the types contributions of non-federal partners for GLLA projects.
  • Great Lakes Legacy Act - Industry Perspectives (PDF)(22 pp, 940 K, March 2016)
    Steven Nadeau presents an industry perspective of the many benefits and few disadvantages of being a partner on a GLLA sediment remediation project.
  • The Non-Federal Sponsor’s (Extremely Vital) Role in GLLA Projects (PDF)(14 pp, 2 MB, March 2016)
    Scott Cieniawski describes the types and role of non-federal sponsors, and the benefit of this cost-sharing program.
  • Recruiting Nonfederal Sponsors: Great Lakes Legacy Act –Partnership Recruitment and Project Development (PDF)(6 pp, 540 K, March 2016)
    Mark Loomis explains methods and tools to recruit project partners for GLLA projects
  • St. Louis River AOC Remedial Action Plan (PDF)(13 pp, 3 MB, March 2016)
    Nelson French describes the St. Louis River AOC remedial action plan development process and roadmap to delisting.
  • Clinton River Area of Concern (PDF)(10 pp, 1 MB, March 2016)
    Anne Vaara outlines the process used by the Clinton River AOC to compile a management action list.
  • A Perspective on Developing Wisconsin’s Management Action Lists (PDF)(10 pp, 657 K, March 2016)
    Kendra Axness gives the state of Wisconsin perspective on developing management actions lists and gives advice on how to overcome challenges.
  • AOC Lessons Learned: an Ohio perspective (PDF)(7 pp, 1 MB, March 2016)
    AmyJo Klei gives the Ohio perspective to developing management action lists and keys to success in the AOC program.
  • Rouge River Area of Concern Projects and Successes (PDF)(22 pp, 4 MB, March 2016)
    Jen Tewkesbury and Aimee LaLonde-Norman discuss the project highlights of the Rouge River AOC and accomplishments of Friends of the Rouge.
  • The AOC "Bucket Challenge" (PDF)(3 pp, 429 K, March 2016)
    Marc Tuchman challenged the 2020+ AOCs to distribute into smaller buckets with specific timeframes for management action completion
  • Conference Interactive Polling Results from Day 1 (PDF)(10 pp, 504 K, March 2016)
    Yearly, questions are asked of conference participants to understand their involvement and understanding of the AOC program.
  • Conference Interactive Polling Results from Day 2 (PDF)(6 pp, 362 K, March 2016)
    Conference Evaluation Results

item.dc:creator: kreshkin

item.title: Restoring the AOCs
item.description:
On this page:
  • What is the process for restoring AOCs?
  • Who does the work and what plan do they follow?
  • How is the restoration work funded?
  • How do we measure progress/results?

Restoration of the Grand Calumet River in Indiana

What is the process for restoring AOCs?

The process for removing Beneficial Use Impairments and delisting AOCs starts with a scientific assessment by the state and federal agencies to determine the extent to which beneficial uses are impaired and the types of management actions required to remediate the AOC. After management actions are implemented, a monitoring and verification plan may be implemented by the state agency, the local public advisory council, EPA and others to determine whether the BUI removal criteria have been met. An AOC is eligible to be delisted when all BUIs have been removed.

Who does the work and what plan do they follow?

The Remedial Action Plan includes management actions necessary for delisting. These are the reasonable and realistic actions that could be taken to remove the relevant BUIs and thus delist the AOC. These actions may not result in the immediate removal of a set of BUIs, but they are expected to remove the contaminant threat that will allow environmental conditions to improve over time and lead to eventual delisting of the AOC.

All management actions necessary for delisting are considered implemented once those actions have commenced and the work is completed over the life of the project. For example, a Legacy Act dredging project that takes place over a 6-month period would be considered a completed management action at the end of that 6-month period.

Top of Page

How is the restoration work funded?

The Great Lakes Restoration Initiative (GLRI), established in 2010, is providing significant resources to remediate and restore the Great Lakes. From 2010-2014, over $2.2 billion has been spent on implementing Great Lakes restoration projects. Of that, over $700 million has been devoted to AOC-related projects.

  • Great Lakes Restoration Initiative Exit
  • Great Lakes Legacy Act

Removing contaminated sediment from White Lake in Michigan.

EPA provides direct funding for the RAP program to the state agency charged with implementing the AOC program. The state agency then distributes those funds to local groups to implement the AOC program.

Within the AOC program, EPA has the lead in removing BUIs and delisting AOCs. Under GLRI, EPA works with other federal agencies to develop and implement programs and fund the states and other local entities to remove BUIs and delist AOCs. Accordingly, EPA manages an ongoing budget and planning cycle with a key group of federal agencies (NOAA, FWS, US Army Corps of Engineers, USGS) to ensure that agency resources are devoted to meeting this goal.  

EPA determines which agency is best able to implement projects based upon their resources and expertise. EPA and these agencies meet on a regular basis and, in conjunction with yearly state agency meetings, plans and budgets are developed that allocate the resources.

Top of Page

How do we measure progress/results?

The federal government created the Interagency Task Force (IATF) which consists of 11 federal agencies collaborating to identify and fund projects. In 2010, the IATF created the GLRI Action Plan that charted a course to address the most pressing Great Lakes problems and set targets to show progress to improve environmental conditions. The GLRI Action Plan II Exit, updated in 2014, has identified two measures of success for the AOC program:

  • AOCs where all management actions necessary for delisting have been implemented
  • AOC BUIs removed

Progress as of 2015

The US has:
  • delisted four AOCs:
    • Oswego River
    • Presque Isle Bay
    • White Lake
    • Deer Lake
  • removed 56 BUIs out of 255
  • completed management actions at three other AOCs
    • Ashtabula River
    • Waukegan Harbor
    • Sheboygan River

Top of Page

Removing BUIs

The process to remove a BUI is:

  1. Complete all management actions necessary to achieve the BUI removal criteria;
  2. Collect the needed data to show the target is met and recommend BUI removal;
  3. Draft data is shared with EPA and it undergoes internal review via EPA and other agency experts. If needed, EPA and the state contacts discuss the data and conclusions.
  4. EPA comments are shared with the State indicating whether EPA concurs that the target has been met.
  5. State and local groups conduct public outreach, offer a public comment period, and acquire local group endorsement of the BUI removal.
  6. State submits the BUI removal request to the Director of the EPA’s Great Lakes National Program Office (GLNPO).
  7. GLNPO Director receives request and, if acceptable, approves the BUI removal request.

Top of Page

Delisting

In 2001, the US Policy Committee for the Great Lakes published Restoring United States Areas of Concern: Delisting Principles and Guidelines, which outlined the steps to delist an AOC. The 2012 Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement (GLWQA) provides new guidance on how to delist an AOC.

EPA maintains a tracking program to measure results and to inform all relevant parties on the progress in achieving the goals outlined in the GLRI Action Plan II. Exit

During 2015-2019, federal agencies will coordinate with the appropriate level of government to provide funding to:

  • implement critical management actions in the remaining AOCs and
  • complete management actions required to delist these ten AOCs:
    • Buffalo River
    • Clinton River
    • Grand Calumet River
    • Manistique River
    • Menominee River
    • Muskegon Lake
    • River Raisin
    • Rochester Embayment
    • St. Clair River
    • St. Marys River

Top of Page
item.dc:creator: kreshkin

item.title: Remedial Action Plans
item.description:
A Remedial Action Plan is a required cleanup plan for all designated AOCs in the Great Lakes basin.

Each state approaches RAP development in different ways. Some have a "hands-on" style of involvement in the process while others delegate much of the decision-making to local groups or agencies within the AOC. 

Components

According to the Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement, each RAP must include the following:

  1. A list identifying which of the 14 Beneficial Use Impairments are present and their causes
  2. The criteria for restoring the BUIs - taking into account local conditions and established in consultation with the local community
  3. Remdial measures to be taken, including identifying the parties that will be responsible for implementing these measures
  4. A summary of the measures taken and and their progress in removing the BUI
  5. The monitoring and evaluation program to track the remedial measures and how they lead to removing the BUI

The RAP includes management actions necessary for delisting. These are the reasonable and realistic actions that could be taken to remove the relevant BUIs and, hence, delist the AOC. These actions may not result in the immediate removal of a set of BUIs, but they are expected to remove the contaminant threat that will allow environmental conditions to improve over time and lead to eventual delisting of the AOC.

All management actions necessary for delisting are considered implemented once those actions have commenced and the work is completed over the life of the project. For example, a Great Lakes Legacy Act dredging project that takes place over a 6-month period would be considered a completed management action at the end of that 6-month period.

Updates

Each state and AOC update their RAPs on a regular basis to reflect  changing local conditions. Cleanup projects may be completed showing progress, studies and analyses of BUI conditions may be completed and other issues may arise that show that BUIs are moving towards removal. RAPs are useful planning and tracking documents that reflect the dynamic nature of the AOC cleanup program.  While RAP updates are no longer referred to by "Stages" due to a change in the 2012 Protocol, they do reflect the ongoing cleanups and changes to the AOC in the pursuit of BUI removal and AOC delisting.

RAPs on State AOC Websites

Other RAP Listings

The following links exit the site Exit

Great Lakes Information Network RAP info

Environment Canada on Great Lakes Areas of Concern

Note: Some states don't produce a general list because they have only one AOC. The following links exit the site Exit

Illinois

  • Waukegan Harbor - RAP is published by the Waukegan Harbor Citizens Advisory Group

Indiana

  • Grand Calumet River

Michigan

  • Michigan Great Lakes Areas of Concern Program - includes the Guidance for Delisting Michigan's Areas of Concern

Minnesota

  • St. Louis River

New York

  • New York Great Lakes Areas of Concern - includes New York's AOC delisting guidance (PDF) (14 pp, 83 K, About PDF) May 2010

Ohio

  • Ohio EPA Lake Erie Programs - includes Ohio AOC Delisting Guidance and Restoration Targets

Pennsylvania

  • Presque Isle Bay AOC has been delisted

Wisconsin

  • Wisconsin DNR Area of Concern Resources - RAPs are specific to their AOCs
    • Lower Green Bay and Fox River
    • Lower Menominee River
    • Milwaukee Estuary
    • Sheboygan River
    • St. Louis River
  • Wisconsin's Great Lakes Areas of Concern - from University of Wisconsin Extension
item.dc:creator: kreshkin

item.title: Beneficial Use Impairments
item.description:
What are Beneficial Use Impairments (BUIs)?

Related Information

BUI listing and delisting info from the International Joint Commission Exit

GLWQA Annexes

AOC Delisting Principles and Guidelines (2001)

An impairment of beneficial uses means a change in the chemical, physical or biological integrity of the Great Lakes system sufficient to cause any of the following:

  1. Restrictions on Fish and Wildlife Consumption
  2. Tainting of Fish and Wildlife Flavor
  3. Degraded Fish and Wildlife Populations
  4. Fish Tumors or Other Deformities
  5. Bird or Animal Deformities or Reproductive Problems
  6. Degradation of Benthos
  7. Restrictions on Dredging Activities
  8. Eutrophication or Undesirable Algae
  9. Restrictions on Drinking Water Consumption or Taste and Odor Problems
  10. Beach Closings
  11. Degradation of Aesthetics
  12. Added Costs to Agriculture or Industry
  13. Degradation of Phytoplankton and Zooplankton Populations
  14. Loss of Fish and Wildlife Habitat

Removing BUIs is based on local restoration targets

Cycle for removing beneficial use impairments (BUIs): determine status, take management actions, assess their impact, propose removal, consult public, remove BUI.
 

In order to address BUIs, each state and local advisory group created restoration targets that define success for each BUI. EPA and other federal agencies did not define explicit targets for each BUI. The International Joint Commission provided some very broad guidance on targets for each BUI in the early 1990s. However, an EPA guidance document offered these criteria for restoration targets:

  • Targets should be premised on local goals and related objectives for the watershed; they should be consistent with applicable federal and state regulations, objectives, guidelines, standards and policies, when available, and the principles and objectives embodied in the AOC Annex 1 in the 2012 Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement.
  • Targets should have measurable indicators and also be realistic and achievable.
  • Targets should be developed and periodically reviewed on a site-specific basis (allowing for flexibility in addressing local conditions) by the respective state agencies in consultation with local stakeholders and other interested parties.  This is important because as new information is developed, the states and local communities are encouraged to modify targets to effectively remove the BUIs.
item.dc:creator: kreshkin
